heading: 3.1 Workers to whom this Agreement applies.
text_raw:
3.1 Workers to whom this Agreement applies. 

This agreement shall apply to workers engaged by an Overhead Powerline 
Contractor anywhere throughout the State i.e.:- 

(a) PICW/Chargehand 

(b) Lineworker 

(c) Trainee Lineworker Phase 2 

(d) Trainee Lineworker Phase 1 

(e) Machine Overhead Line Operator 

(f) PICP 

(g) General Assistant

(b) Any other worker not referred to above.

title: Relations Act 1946 (No. 26 of 1946), being satisfied that subsections (1) to (5)
heading: 4. DEFINITIONS
text_raw: 4. DEFINITIONS
text_norm: 4 definition

title: Relations Act 1946 (No. 26 of 1946), being satisfied that subsections (1) to (5)
heading: 4.1 In this Agreement
text_raw:
4.1 In this Agreement 

(a) An Overhead Powerline Contractor (OPC) is defined as a 
company who as part of its business carries out the maintenance, 
construction and refurbishment of overhead powerlines, poles 
and towers on site, on a contract or sub-contract basis. No 
individual workers will be engaged as sub-contractors under this 
or any other agreement associated with this agreement. 

 
 
 
 
 
 4 [229] 

(b) A site is the exact location where overhead powerline work is 

being carried out. 

(c) Overhead powerline work is defined as the maintenance, 
refurbishment and adaptation of overhead 

construction, 
powerlines, poles and towers and associated structures on site. 

(d) 

“Employment agreement” means an agreement relating to the 
remuneration or the conditions of employment of workers of any 
class, type or group made between a trade union of workers and 
an employer or trade union of employers or made, at a meeting 
of a registered joint industrial council, between members of the 
council representative of workers represented by the Union and 
members of the council representative of employers.

4.2 Joint Industrial Council

registered with the Labour Court.

title: Relations Act 1946 (No. 26 of 1946), being satisfied that subsections (1) to (5)
heading: 4.3 Job Classes
text_raw:
4.3 Job Classes 

PICW/Chargehand (Person in Charge of Works) 

A person who has a minimum of four years’ service, consisting of two years as 
a Trainee Lineworker and a further two years as a Lineworker or who is 
already established as a Lineworker and is currently engaged in the overhead 
powerline work. The PICW is the assigned person trained and assessed by the 
ESB with the overall responsibility to manage the site. He/She is responsible to 
carry out the work safely in accordance with safety rules and has the final say 
on work duties on site. 

Lineworker 

A person who, after the establishment of this order, has successfully completed 
their Trainee Lineworker Phase 1 & Phase 2 training (24 months duration), or 
who is already established as a Lineworker and is engaged in overhead 
powerline work. 

Trainee Lineworker Phase 2 

A person who has successfully completed and passed his/her 12month Trainee 
Lineworker Phase 1. He/she will now undertake a further 12-month 
comprehensive training programme (agreed by all parties) under the guidance 
of a certified Lineworker and is engaged in overhead powerline work. 
Appendix 2 

Trainee Lineworker Phase 1 

A person who is undertaking a 12-month comprehensive training programme 
(agreed by all parties) under the guidance of a certified Lineworker and is 
engaged in overhead powerline work. Appendix 2 A Phase 1 trainee lineworker 
must successfully complete and pass all training modules before progressing to 
Phase 2 trainee lineworker. 

 
 
 
 [229] 5 

A company may not employ more than one Trainee Lineworker for every 4 
Lineworkers employed by the company on a contract. 

PICP (Person in Charge of Poling) 

A person trained and assessed by the ESB with overall responsibility of the 
poling work and is responsible for carrying out all poling work in accordance 
with the safety rules. 

Machine Overhead Line Operator. 

A person trained and assessed by the ESB who operates the excavator safely. 

He/she will coordinate and cooperate with the PICW or PICP on all workrelated matters. 

General Duties Assistant 

A person wholly or mainly engaged on site assisting from the ground in all 
aspects of Powerline Work.
text_norm: 4.3 job class picw chargehand (person charge works) person minimum four year service consisting two year trainee lineworker two year lineworker already established lineworker currently engaged overhead powerline work picw assigned person trained assessed esb overall responsibility manage site responsible carry work safely accordance safety rule final say work duty site lineworker person establishment order successfully completed trainee lineworker phase 1 phase 2 training (24 month duration) already established lineworker engaged overhead powerline work trainee lineworker phase 2 person successfully completed passed 12month trainee lineworker phase 1 undertake 12-month comprehensive training programme (agreed parties) guidance certified lineworker engaged overhead powerline work appendix 2 trainee lineworker phase 1 person undertaking 12-month comprehensive training programme (agreed parties) guidance certified lineworker engaged overhead powerline work appendix 2 phase 1 trainee lineworker must successfully complete pas training module progressing phase 2 trainee lineworker 229 5 company may employ one trainee lineworker every 4 lineworkers employed company contract picp (person charge poling) person trained assessed esb overall responsibility poling work responsible carrying poling work accordance safety rule machine overhead line operator person trained assessed esb operates excavator safely coordinate cooperate picw picp workrelated matter general duty assistant person wholly mainly engaged site assisting ground aspect powerline work

title: Relations Act 1946 (No. 26 of 1946), being satisfied that subsections (1) to (5)
heading: 5. UNION RECOGNITION AND UNION MEMBERSHIP
text_raw:
5. UNION RECOGNITION AND UNION MEMBERSHIP 

(a) Connect Trade Union is recognised as the only Union with 
negotiating rights in respect of the categories of employees 
coming within the scope of this Agreement. 

(b) 

It shall remain a condition of all workers to whom this 
agreement relates who commence employment after 
the 
establishment date of this agreement that they shall become and 
remain in benefit members of the Union. 

(c) The Company recognises the Union’s right to represent its 
members in matters relating to terms and conditions of 
employment and in matters covered by this agreement and 
appropriate facilities will be provided to its representatives. 

(d) The Company shall have the sole right to recruit employees 
into 
from any source and 
membership any employee recruited by the Company, provided 
such a person shall be eligible for membership according to the 
rules of the Union and according to the provisions of this 
Agreement. 

the Union agrees 

to accept 

(e) Upon authorisation in writing by employees through their Union 
the Company will deduct weekly from payroll a sum equivalent 
to the members’ dues and remit such amounts monthly to the 
Union. 

(f) The Company will be in no way liable in the event of any 
dispute arising between the Union and its members regarding 
such deductions. 

 
 
 
 
 6 [229]

title: Relations Act 1946 (No. 26 of 1946), being satisfied that subsections (1) to (5)
heading: 6. PROBATIONARY PERIOD OF EMPLOYMENT
text_raw:
6. PROBATIONARY PERIOD OF EMPLOYMENT 

(a) All personnel (including Trainee Lineworkers) shall initially be 
employed for a period of six months on a probationary basis, 
during this period employment may be terminated at any time if, 
in the opinion of the Company, which shall be conclusive, the 
person is not suitable. The probationary period may be extended 
if necessary by a maximum of 6 months. The reason/s of which 
will be recorded in writing. 

(b) During the probationary period, employees shall be subject to 
the Minimum notice and Terms of Employment Act 1973.

title: Relations Act 1946 (No. 26 of 1946), being satisfied that subsections (1) to (5)
heading: 7.1 (c)
text_raw:
7.1 (c) 

Normal Working Time and Unsocial Hours Payments 

The following definitions shall apply in respect of hours worked by OHPL 
Grades and Trainees in the sector:- 

Normal Working Week 

Normal Working week shall consist of 39 hours worked between Monday and 
Friday each week. 

Normal Daily Working Hours 

Normal daily working hours shall consist of eight consecutive hours of work 
undertaken between the hours of 7 am and 5 pm (Normal weekday finishing 
time) Monday – Thursday inclusive and between the hours of 7 am and 4 pm 
(normal Friday finishing time) on Friday (7 consecutive hours) 

Other Hours Worked 

Hours worked outside of the basic hours shall constitute overtime working 
hours and shall attract the following premium payments:- 

Hours worked between normal 
finishing time and Midnight Monday 
to Friday inclusive 

Time plus a half 

Hours worked between Midnight and 
normal starting time Monday to 
Friday 

Double time 

First four hours worked on Saturday, 
assuming the normal start time of 

Time plus a half 

 
 
 [229] 7 

Monday to Friday 

All other hours worked on Saturday 

Double time 

All hours worked on Sunday 

Double time 

All hours worked on Public Holidays Double time plus an additional day’s 

leave 

(a) Only overtime worked on the instructions of the Company will 

be paid for. 

(b) All employees are obliged to work a reasonable amount of 

overtime, if and when required by the Company. 

(c) 

If an employee agrees to work an overtime schedule, he/she 
must adhere to the established scheduled commencement time 
and duration. 

Unsocial Hours Worked 

Where for specific projects hours are required to differ from those set out at 
“Normal Daily Working Hours” above, the following rates should apply: 

Where the starting time is before 1pm First 8 hours (worked before 

• 
Midnight) at time plus one quarter 

Where starting time is after 1pm First 8 hours (worked before 

• 
Midnight) at time plus one third 

• 

Overtime is then paid at the correct premium rate by overtime rate.

title: Relations Act 1946 (No. 26 of 1946), being satisfied that subsections (1) to (5)
Relations Act 1946 (No. 26 of 1946), being satisfied that subsections (1) to (5)
Relations Act 1946 (No. 26 of 1946), being satisfied that subsections (1) to (5)
heading: 8.2 Reporting on Site
text_raw:
8.2 Reporting on Site 

Employees will be expected to report to a suitable yard/depo at a normal 
starting time and no travel time is payable under the terms of this agreement. 
However, in the event of an employee being requested to use his own vehicle 
in the course of the business of the company, then a payment equivalent to the 
civil service mileage allowance will be payable.

title: Relations Act 1946 (No. 26 of 1946), being satisfied that subsections (1) to (5)
heading: 8.3 Eating on Site
text_raw:
8.3 Eating on Site 

A minimum of €8.00 tax free eating on site allowance to be paid daily to each 
employee covered by this agreement.
text_norm: 8.3 eating site minimum eur8.00 tax free eating site allowance paid daily employee covered agreement

title: Relations Act 1946 (No. 26 of 1946), being satisfied that subsections (1) to (5)
heading: 8.4 Overnight Allowance
text_raw:
8.4 Overnight Allowance 

(a) An overnight allowance covers a period of up to 24 hours which 
is necessarily spent overnight and is in excess of 50 Kilometres 
away from the person’s normal place of residence, where 
accommodation is not provided by the employer. The rate of 
overnight allowance will be €80 per night. 

(b) A minimum sum of €15.00 tax free will be paid daily for lunch 

if / when required to stay overnight. 

(c) 

In circumstances where suitable overnight accommodation and 
lunch is provided by the company, then overnight allowance and 
lunch allowance is not payable. 

(d) On the day following the last payable overnight allowance an 

allowance of €40 will be payable.

title: Relations Act 1946 (No. 26 of 1946), being satisfied that subsections (1) to (5)
heading: 9. ANNUAL LEAVE & HOLIDAY PAY
text_raw:
9. ANNUAL LEAVE & HOLIDAY PAY 

(a) An employee covered under this agreement shall receive 
holidays with pay in accordance with the provisions of the 
Organisation of Working Time Act, 1997, or any amendments 
thereof. 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 [229] 9 

(b) The holiday year will be from January 1 to December 31 year, 
during which there will be a minimum of 22 days annual leave 
for all employees.
text_norm: 9 annual leave holiday pay (a) employee covered agreement shall receive holiday pay accordance provision organisation working time act 1997 amendment thereof 229 9 (b) holiday year january 1 december 31 year minimum 22 day annual leave employee

title: Relations Act 1946 (No. 26 of 1946), being satisfied that subsections (1) to (5)
heading: 10. PUBLIC HOLIDAYS
text_raw:
10. PUBLIC HOLIDAYS 

(a) Public Holidays will be calculated and paid in accordance with 
the Organisation of Working Time Act, 1997, or such days as 
may be declared by law to be Public Holidays in lieu or in 
addition to those already in being. 

(b) An employee shall in respect of a designated Public Holiday, be 

entitled to: 

I. 

II. 

a paid day off on that day, or 

a paid day off within a month, or 

III. an extra day’s annual leave, or 

IV. an extra day’s pay as the employer may decide. 

(c) Payment of overtime for work done on a Public Holiday shall be 
at treble time or at double time plus a day off at a mutually 
acceptable later date.

title: Relations Act 1946 (No. 26 of 1946), being satisfied that subsections (1) to (5)
heading: PROTECTIVE CLOTHING
text_raw:
11. 

PROTECTIVE CLOTHING 

The employer will provide all personal protective equipment and the tools 
necessary to carry out the duties assigned. The employee is responsible for the 
safe keeping and maintenance of any items issued and will be liable to pay 
replacement costs where such items are lost or damaged as a result of failure to 
keep such items safe or careless use.

title: Relations Act 1946 (No. 26 of 1946), being satisfied that subsections (1) to (5)
heading: 12.1 Disciplinary and Grievance Procedure at the Enterprise Level
text_raw:
12.1 Disciplinary and Grievance Procedure at the Enterprise Level 

Each company must have in place a disciplinary and grievance procedure in 

accordance with S.I. No. 146/2000 — Industrial Relations Act, 1990 (Code of 
Practice on Grievance and Disciplinary Procedures) (Declaration) Order, 2000
text_norm: 12.1 disciplinary grievance procedure enterprise level company must place disciplinary grievance procedure accordance s.i no 146 2000 -- industrial relation act 1990 (code practice grievance disciplinary procedures) (declaration) order 2000

title: Relations Act 1946 (No. 26 of 1946), being satisfied that subsections (1) to (5)
heading: 12.2 Disputes Procedure
text_raw:
12.2 Disputes Procedure 

(a) All disputes not involving matters of interpretation of this 
agreement, which are not resolved at the level of the enterprise, 
shall be referred to the Workplace Relation Commission or a 
WRC Adjudicator for resolution as appropriate. 

(b) Where the WRC Adjudicator or the Workplace Relations 
Commission fail to resolve the matter, the grievance shall be 
referred to the Labour Court. 

 
 
 
 
 
 10 [229] 

(c) No employee may take industrial action or commence in a 
“lock-out” until after the rejection of a Labour Court or the 
WRC Adjudicator’s Recommendation and then only after the 
expiry of at least 14 days written notice to the employer by the 
Union. All the procedures set out in Rule 12 will be exhausted 
before industrial action is taken. 

(d) Where a dispute has arisen within an enterprise and with the 
agreement of the parties a dispute may be referred to the NJIC 
for binding arbitration.
text_norm: 12.2 dispute procedure (a) dispute involving matter interpretation agreement resolved level enterprise shall referred workplace relation commission wrc adjudicator resolution appropriate (b) wrc adjudicator workplace relation commission fail resolve matter grievance shall referred labour court 10 229 (c) employee may take industrial action commence lock-out rejection labour court wrc adjudicator recommendation expiry least 14 day written notice employer union procedure set rule 12 exhausted industrial action taken (d) dispute arisen within enterprise agreement party dispute may referred njic binding arbitration

title: Relations Act 1946 (No. 26 of 1946), being satisfied that subsections (1) to (5)
heading: 12.3 Matters of Interpretation
text_raw:
12.3 Matters of Interpretation 

(a) No stoppage of work go slow, or lock-out shall take place on the 

interpretation of these Rules. 

(b) Should a dispute arise in relation to the interpretation of any part 
of this Agreement the matter will be referred to the National 
Joint Industrial Council (NJIC) for resolution. 

(c) Any matter of interpretation not resolved at the NJIC shall be 
referred to the Labour Court for decision in accordance with 
Section 20 (2) of the Industrial Relations Act 1969.
text_norm: 12.3 matter interpretation (a) stoppage work go slow lock-out shall take place interpretation rule (b) dispute arise relation interpretation part agreement matter referred national joint industrial council (njic) resolution (c) matter interpretation resolved njic shall referred labour court decision accordance section 20 (2) industrial relation act 1969

title: Relations Act 1946 (No. 26 of 1946), being satisfied that subsections (1) to (5)
heading: 13. HEALTH AND SAFETY
text_raw:
13. HEALTH AND SAFETY 

(a) Companies shall make reasonable provision for the safety and 
health of its employees during the hours of their employment, 
and shall abide by its obligations under the Safety, Health and 
Welfare at Work Act, 2005.
text_norm: 13 health safety (a) company shall make reasonable provision safety health employee hour employment shall abide obligation safety health welfare work act 2005

title: Relations Act 1946 (No. 26 of 1946), being satisfied that subsections (1) to (5)
heading: 14. UNOFFICIAL ACTION
text_raw:
14. UNOFFICIAL ACTION 

In the event of unofficial action occurring, no money will be paid by the 
employer to Employees concerned, neither the union nor management will 
negotiate until there is a resumption of normal work. The union will make 
every effort to bring about a resumption as soon as possible. 

Where the appropriate Management and trade union agree, a trade union 
official shall go to the particular site as soon as possible to obtain a resumption 
of normal work.
text_norm: 14 unofficial action event unofficial action occurring money paid employer employee concerned neither union management negotiate resumption normal work union make every effort bring resumption soon possible appropriate management trade union agree trade union official shall go particular site soon possible obtain resumption normal work

title: Relations Act 1946 (No. 26 of 1946), being satisfied that subsections (1) to (5)
heading: 15. SICK PAY, DEATH in SERVICE Benefit AND PENSION
text_raw:
15. SICK PAY, DEATH in SERVICE Benefit AND PENSION 

SCHEME 

A Sick Pay Scheme and Pension Scheme equal in benefits to the Construction 
Workers Pension Scheme (CWPS) shall apply to all workers covered by the 
Scope of this agreement. For the avoidance of doubt unless a Sick Pay, 
Pension and Mortality Scheme is equal or better that the Construction Workers 
Pension Scheme then the Construction Workers Pension Scheme will apply. 
This Clause will have application to all companies carrying out works covered 

 
 
 
 
 
 [229] 11 

by the Scope of this agreement whether they have headquarters outside of 
Ireland or not. 

In addition, contributions to the Construction Workers Health Trust and 
Benevolent Funds to be deducted and forwarded to the Trust as part of the 
CWPS contributions.
text_norm: 15 sick pay death service benefit pension scheme sick pay scheme pension scheme equal benefit construction worker pension scheme (cwps) shall apply worker covered scope agreement avoidance doubt unless sick pay pension mortality scheme equal better construction worker pension scheme construction worker pension scheme apply clause application company carrying work covered 229 11 scope agreement whether headquarters outside ireland not addition contribution construction worker health trust benevolent fund deducted forwarded trust part cwps contribution

title: Relations Act 1946 (No. 26 of 1946), being satisfied that subsections (1) to (5)
heading: 16. BEREAVEMENT LEAVE
text_raw:
16. BEREAVEMENT LEAVE 

A maximum of 3 days’ paid leave will be allowed in the case of bereavement 
of close relatives. The employer will be notified as soon as possible of the 
bereavement. The term close relative means, spouse, parent, child, brother or 
sister.
text_norm: 16 bereavement leave maximum 3 day paid leave allowed case bereavement close relative employer notified soon possible bereavement term close relative mean spouse parent child brother sister

title: Relations Act 1946 (No. 26 of 1946), being satisfied that subsections (1) to (5)
heading: 17. WAGE REVIEW
text_raw:
17. WAGE REVIEW 

This agreement will be reviewed on 1st October 2022 and on an agreed basis 
thereafter.
text_norm: 17 wage review agreement reviewed 1st october 2022 agreed basis thereafter

title: Relations Act 1946 (No. 26 of 1946), being satisfied that subsections (1) to (5)
heading: 19. CERTIFICATE OF SERVICE
text_raw:
19. CERTIFICATE OF SERVICE 

Each worker shall be entitled to request from his or her employer on 
termination of his or her employment, a certificate of service showing the 
period of such employment, in each particular grade/position in which he or 
she may have been employed.
text_norm: 19 certificate service worker shall entitled request employer termination employment certificate service showing period employment particular grade position may employed

title: Relations Act 1946 (No. 26 of 1946), being satisfied that subsections (1) to (5)
heading: 20. TERMINATION OF AGREEMENT
text_raw:
20. TERMINATION OF AGREEMENT 

Either party will have the right to terminate the contract by giving written 
notice to the other party at least 6 months before the end of the initial period of 
the contract or at least 3 months at any point after the end of the initial period.
text_norm: 20 termination agreement either party right terminate contract giving written notice party least 6 month end initial period contract least 3 month point end initial period

title: Relations Act 1946 (No. 26 of 1946), being satisfied that subsections (1) to (5)
heading: 21. COMPLIANCE & ENFORCEMENT
text_raw:
21. COMPLIANCE & ENFORCEMENT 

(a) The Overhead Powerline Contractors (OPC’s), Connect Trade 
Union and the client companies are all equally affected by the 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 12 [229] 

implementation of this agreement in each and every contract 
now and in the future. 

(b) The parties covered by this agreement are fully committed to its 

terms and will act at all times to preserve its integrity. 

(c) To this end a client company must employ the services of an 
Audit Services Company (agreed at the NJIC) at least once a 
year to conduct an audit or investigation into any contractor 
engaged by them relating to the Terms and Conditions of 
Employment within an Overhead Powerline Contractor business 
that is carrying out works on behalf of that client company. 

(d) All 

Overhead 

their 
employee/members of the union will co-operate fully with any 
such audit or investigation. 

Contractors 

Powerline 

and 

(e) 

Information gathered by an Audit Services Company for the 
purpose of compliance with this agreement may be made 
available to the NJIC with a view to rectifying any breach of the 
Agreement. 

(f) Notwithstanding clause (e) above union delegates with written 
authority from the union shall be entitled to visit jobs and places 
of work during working hours for the purpose of ensuring 
compliance with this agreement.

title: Relations Act 1946 (No. 26 of 1946), being satisfied that subsections (1) to (5)
heading: 22. EQUAL TREATMENT
text_raw:
22. EQUAL TREATMENT 

(a) The Union agrees to maintain the terms of this agreement and 
the obligations and benefits attaching thereto with all other 
Employer Groups of Individual Employers doing similar work. 

(b) The employers on their part agree that they will not make any 
agreement altering the terms of this agreement with any other 
Union, Association or Individual engaged in similar work
text_norm: 22 equal treatment (a) union agrees maintain term agreement obligation benefit attaching thereto employer group individual employer similar work (b) employer part agree make agreement altering term agreement union association individual engaged similar work

title: Relations Act 1946 (No. 26 of 1946), being satisfied that subsections (1) to (5)
heading: 23. TRANSITIONAL ARRANGEMENTS
text_raw:
23. TRANSITIONAL ARRANGEMENTS 

Date of Agreement: While it is the intention to register this agreement with the 
Labour Court, and all parties are committed to bringing this about as soon as 
may be, the implementation date of this agreement is agreed between the 
parties to the agreement as of 1st November 2021 

 
 
 
 
 
 Signed:ON BEHALF OF THE OPCGON BEHALF OF CONNECT

heading: 1. The Council is established to promote harmonious relations between
text_raw:

Companies engaged in Overhead Powerline Contractors Industry and the 
workers employed by them for the carrying out of their business.

heading: 2. Membership of the Council is open to employees engaged in overhead
text_raw:
2. Membership of the Council is open to employees engaged in overhead 
power line work, Connect Trade Union officials and Overhead Powerline 
Contractors.

title: Relations Act 1946 (No. 26 of 1946), being satisfied that subsections (1) to (5)
heading: 3. The Council shall consist of eight members, a Chairperson and Official
text_raw:
3. The Council shall consist of eight members, a Chairperson and Official 
Secretary. The Chairperson and Official Secretary shall be appointed by the 
Labour Court at the request of the Council members.

title: Relations Act 1946 (No. 26 of 1946), being satisfied that subsections (1) to (5)
heading: 5. Side Secretaries, who shall be one of the members referred to in clause
text_raw:
5. Side Secretaries, who shall be one of the members referred to in clause 
4 above, shall be appointed by the employer representatives for the employer 
side and the employee representatives for the employee side. The Chairperson 
shall be notified of the name of the Side Secretaries appointed. A Side 
Secretary will hold their position at the discretion of the nominating body or 
until his/her resignation from the position.

title: Relations Act 1946 (No. 26 of 1946), being satisfied that subsections (1) to (5)
heading: If by reason of illness or other sufficient cause any member is unable to
text_raw:
6. 

If by reason of illness or other sufficient cause any member is unable to 
be present at a meeting of the Council the employers’ or the workers’ side as 
the case may be, shall nominate a deputy to attend the meeting and exercise all 
the functions conferred on the member by the constitution. The names of 
representatives appointed by the Employers and Connect Trade Union shall be 
notified to the Official Secretary of the Council.
text_norm: 6 reason illness sufficient cause member unable present meeting council employer worker side case may shall nominate deputy attend meeting exercise function conferred member constitution name representative appointed employer connect trade union shall notified official secretary council

title: Relations Act 1946 (No. 26 of 1946), being satisfied that subsections (1) to (5)
heading: 7. The members shall hold office for so long as the nominating bodies
text_raw:
7. The members shall hold office for so long as the nominating bodies 
shall think fit. Should any vacancy occur by resignation or otherwise, the 
vacancy shall be filled by the appointment to the Council of another member 
by the body which appointed the retired member.

title: Relations Act 1946 (No. 26 of 1946), being satisfied that subsections (1) to (5)
heading: It will be the duty of the Official Secretary, in consultation with the
text_raw:
9. 

It will be the duty of the Official Secretary, in consultation with the 
Chairperson and Side Secretaries, to summon meetings of the Council, to 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 [229] 15 

prepare the agenda of the meetings, which shall be circulated not less than 7 
days before the meeting, to keep minutes of proceedings and generally to carry 
out the instructions of the Council and Chairperson in all matters relating to the 
proper working of the Council and the promotion of its objects.

title: Relations Act 1946 (No. 26 of 1946), being satisfied that subsections (1) to (5)
heading: 10. The duties of a Side Secretary shall be to summon separate meetings of
text_raw:
10. The duties of a Side Secretary shall be to summon separate meetings of 
his/her side for the consideration of any matters to be brought before the 
Council. When a meeting of the Council is desired by either side the Secretary 
of that side shall notify the Official Secretary of the Council and shall forward 
details of the business which that side desires to be put on the agenda of the 
meeting and the said meeting shall be called within fourteen days of receipt of 
request.
text_norm: 10 duty side secretary shall summon separate meeting side consideration matter brought council meeting council desired either side secretary side shall notify official secretary council shall forward detail business side desire put agenda meeting said meeting shall called within fourteen day receipt request

title: Relations Act 1946 (No. 26 of 1946), being satisfied that subsections (1) to (5)
heading: 11. A quorum shall consist of a Chairperson and at least two on each side
text_raw:
11. A quorum shall consist of a Chairperson and at least two on each side 

of the Council.
text_norm: 11 quorum shall consist chairperson least two side council

title: Relations Act 1946 (No. 26 of 1946), being satisfied that subsections (1) to (5)
heading: 12. In pursuance of its objectives, the Council shall be the negotiating body
text_raw:
12. In pursuance of its objectives, the Council shall be the negotiating body 
in respect of wages and conditions of employment for all categories of staff 
covered by the Collective Agreement for the Overhead Powerline Contracting 
Industry.
text_norm: 12 pursuance objective council shall negotiating body respect wage condition employment category staff covered collective agreement overhead powerline contracting industry

title: Relations Act 1946 (No. 26 of 1946), being satisfied that subsections (1) to (5)
heading: 13. In the event of a dispute arising between all or any of the members of
text_raw:
13. In the event of a dispute arising between all or any of the members of 
the union represented on the Council and all or any of the individual firms 
represented on the Council by the employer organisation, the matters in dispute 
if not settled between the firm and the union locally may be referred to the 
Council. If the Council is unable to resolve the issue in dispute, the matter 
shall be referred to Arbitration or to the Labour Court and no strike, lock-out or 
interference with normal working operations shall take place before the 
Arbitrator has issued his findings or the Court has made a recommendation.
text_norm: 13 event dispute arising member union represented council individual firm represented council employer organisation matter dispute settled firm union locally may referred council council unable resolve issue dispute matter shall referred arbitration labour court strike lock-out interference normal working operation shall take place arbitrator issued finding court made recommendation

title: Relations Act 1946 (No. 26 of 1946), being satisfied that subsections (1) to (5)
heading: 14. The Council shall have the power to appoint a sub-committee to deal
text_raw:
14. The Council shall have the power to appoint a sub-committee to deal 
with any particular matter and such sub-committee shall report to the parent 
body.
text_norm: 14 council shall power appoint sub-committee deal particular matter sub-committee shall report parent body

title: Relations Act 1946 (No. 26 of 1946), being satisfied that subsections (1) to (5)
heading: 15. The Council shall have power to alter this constitution by consent of the
text_raw:
15. The Council shall have power to alter this constitution by consent of the 
two sides of the Council but only at a special meeting summoned for the 
purpose and as a general rule, amendments may only be made once every three 
years. 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 16 [229] 

APPENDIX 2: 

This two phase, 24 month duration comprehensive training program will 
continue to be discussed and negotiated between Connect Trade Union and the 
Overhead Powerline Contractors Group. 

Upon agreement, the complete training module contents will form part of this 
National Collective Agreement signed 1st November 2021 

Until this comprehensive training program content is agreed by both parties, 
the established training programs provided by each individual company will 
remain in place. 

GIVEN under my hand, 
 11 May 2023 

NEALE RICHMOND, 
 Minister of State at the Department of Enterprise, Trade and 

Employment. 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 [229] 17

heading: (This note is not part of the Instrument and does not purpose to be a legal
text_raw:
EXPLANATORY NOTE 

(This note is not part of the Instrument and does not purpose to be a legal 
interpretation.) 

The purpose of this Order is to set out the agreed terms and conditions from 1st 
November 2021 to apply to the workers specified who are engaged by an 
Overhead Powerline Contractor.
